a221c5d35d600e868acdae877395c119.title: Claude Code is down due to a major outage
a221c5d35d600e868acdae877395c119.summary: Anthropic's Claude AI models experienced a significant outage, affecting products like Claude Code. Developers encountered errors while trying to use the service, but a fix was implemented within 20 minutes.
a221c5d35d600e868acdae877395c119.full_text:
Anthropic’s Claude AI models experienced a major outage today, impacting products like Claude Code. Developers were seeing a 500 error when trying to use Claude Code, and Anthropic said that it was seeing elevated error rates on its APIs 'across all Claude models.'

Anthropic quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix within around 20 minutes, but developers that rely on the tool were left staring at their screens waiting for the service to come back online. Claude Opus 4.5 also experienced some errors yesterday, and earlier this week Anthropic had to fix purchasing issues for its AI credits system.

It’s unusual to see Claude Code experience a major outage like this, especially as the service is used widely by developers, including Microsoft’s AI teams.

***Update, February 3rd**: Anthropic has now resolved its Claude API outage.*

images.description: Image related to Claude Code outage.

d19aaf3ad63cde88b8ab99f07eb43cb8.summary: Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are set to launch their new AI models around the Spring Festival, with significant advancements expected in various capabilities. The industry is anticipating these releases to redefine AI applications.
d19aaf3ad63cde88b8ab99f07eb43cb8.full_text:
Recently, there have been reports that Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are planning to launch their new generation of AI models around the Spring Festival, which has attracted widespread attention in the industry.

Zhipu AI's GLM-5 model is expected to be officially released one week before the start of the Lunar New Year on February 15. According to internal information, this new model will achieve breakthroughs in areas such as creative writing, programming, reasoning, and intelligent agent capabilities, and is likely to redefine the way AI is applied. The release of GLM-5 is highly anticipated, with the industry expecting it to bring substantial improvements in multiple areas, especially in intelligent writing and code generation.

At the same time, MiniMax is not lagging behind, and will release its M2.2 version before the Spring Festival. This is an upgraded version of its previous model M2.1, focusing on enhancing programming capabilities and is expected to provide developers with more efficient tools and solutions. Industry analysts believe that MiniMax M2.2 will become a "secret weapon" for programmers, helping them complete complex tasks more quickly.

Meanwhile, DeepSeek may only make minor updates to its V3 series model around the Spring Festival. The future flagship model is expected to be an AI with a trillion parameters, although due to the longer training time, its release date has been postponed. This news has undoubtedly increased market expectations, especially against the backdrop of increasingly fierce competition in large language models.

In addition to these companies' new developments, ByteDance and Alibaba also plan to launch their next-generation AI models around the Spring Festival in 2026, further intensifying market competition. ByteDance is expected to release Doubao 2.0 (a large language model), Seedream 5.0 (an image generation model), and SeedDance 2.0 (a video generation model), while Alibaba will launch Qwen 3.5, focusing on reasoning and complex task capabilities. The release of these new models will cover multi-modal generation capabilities including text, images, and videos, demonstrating the continuous expansion of AI product lines.

In conclusion, as the footsteps of the Spring Festival approach, the AI industry will experience a wave of new releases, and the industry is full of anticipation for future technological innovations.

01499f50c55a22ba5e47a3d307d8f52d.title: Claude Code is down due to a major outage
01499f50c55a22ba5e47a3d307d8f52d.summary: Anthropic's Claude AI models experienced a significant outage, affecting products like Claude Code. The issue was identified and resolved within 20 minutes, but developers faced disruptions during the downtime.
01499f50c55a22ba5e47a3d307d8f52d.full_text:
Anthropic’s Claude AI models experienced a major outage today, impacting products like Claude Code. Developers were seeing a 500 error when trying to use Claude Code, and Anthropic said that it was seeing elevated error rates on its APIs 'across all Claude models.'

Anthropic quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix within around 20 minutes, but developers that rely on the tool were left staring at their screens waiting for the service to come back online. Claude Opus 4.5 also experienced some errors yesterday, and earlier this week Anthropic had to fix purchasing issues for its AI credits system.

It’s unusual to see Claude Code experience a major outage like this, especially as the service is used widely by developers, including Microsoft’s AI teams.

***Update, February 3rd**: Anthropic has now resolved its Claude API outage.*

images.description: Image related to Claude Code outage

2d41dcc17c1c668c609af2f14aad0c6e.title: French police raid X’s Paris office as UK investigation continues
2d41dcc17c1c668c609af2f14aad0c6e.summary: French police conducted a raid on X's Paris office as part of an ongoing investigation that includes allegations against the company and its AI tool, Grok. The investigation has drawn attention to serious allegations including child pornography and Holocaust denial.
2d41dcc17c1c668c609af2f14aad0c6e.full_text:
A raid on X’s Paris office was carried out by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit on Tuesday with Europol and French police as part of an ongoing investigation that expanded in July to include Grok. As previously reported by Reuters, Elon Musk and former X CEO Linda Yaccarino were also summoned for hearings in April.

The investigation, which was initially launched last year, is looking into several allegations against X and Grok, including complicity in possession and distribution of child pornography and denial of crimes against humanity (related to Holocaust denial content), along with claims that X was manipulating its algorithm and illegally extracting data.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and “its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.” It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still “gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.”

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

images.description: X logo displayed in the article.
Author of the article, Stevie Bonifield.

626addfa9e9e793403f403d01074b89d.title: How Anthropic trained its AI models on millions of books | The Verge
626addfa9e9e793403f403d01074b89d.summary: This article discusses the methods used by Anthropic to train its AI models, including the controversial practice of scanning millions of books. It also touches on the implications of these practices in the tech industry.
626addfa9e9e793403f403d01074b89d.full_text:
On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

by David Pierce

Feb 3, 2026, 10:19 AM EST

When ChatGPT launched, in November of 2022, it started a race that almost immediately consumed the tech industry. OpenAI didn’t invent the concept of AI, but most of the state-of-the-art technology was confined to research labs at companies and institutions around the world. Then, suddenly, it was everywhere. And better than anyone expected. So many companies decided they needed to catch up as quickly as possible, by any means necessary, or risk losing the battle for maybe the most important technology ever.

On this episode of The Vergecast, we talk about one version of that scramble. The Washington Post’s Will Oremus joins the show to talk about the details he and his team uncovered about “Project Panama,” a huge effort inside Anthropic to access and digitize vast quantities of book in order to feed them into large language models. Anthropic’s plan — which included book cutters, piracy websites, and enormous warehouses — sounds a lot like what’s happening at other companies, too. The fight over whether any of it is right, legally or morally, is very much ongoing.

After that, Puck’s Julia Alexander joins the show to talk Netflix and the movies. As it continues to try to buy Warner Bros, Netflix is saying all the right things about movie theaters, big-budget films, and generally caring about Hollywood. But of course it is — it’s trying to buy Warner Bros.! Once this all shakes out, can theaters survive in an increasingly Netflix-ified world? Do people even want to see Netflix movies in theaters? And if not, what do we do with these big buildings and their big screens? Luckily we have some ideas.

Finally, The Verge’s Jennifer Pattison Tuohy answers a question from the Vergecast Hotline about Ikea’s new smart buttons and why they don’t seem to work very well. In terrific news, one part of our conversation is already outdated: since we recorded this on Monday morning, Google announced button support for Google Home! Huge day for Mike, our caller. But the problems with Ikea’s exciting new low-cost smart gear still persist.

images.description: David Pierce is editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech.

1a43b175b0a19e1656ff07ef7c33e96c.title: French police raid X’s Paris office as UK investigation continues
1a43b175b0a19e1656ff07ef7c33e96c.summary: A raid on X’s Paris office was conducted by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit as part of an ongoing investigation into several allegations against X and Grok. The investigation has expanded to include testimonies from Elon Musk and Linda Yaccarino.
1a43b175b0a19e1656ff07ef7c33e96c.full_text:
A raid on X’s Paris office was carried out by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit on Tuesday with Europol and French police as part of an ongoing investigation that expanded in July to include Grok. As previously reported by Reuters, Elon Musk and former X CEO Linda Yaccarino were also summoned for hearings in April.

The investigation, which was initially launched last year, is looking into several allegations against X and Grok, including complicity in possession and distribution of child pornography and denial of crimes against humanity (related to Holocaust denial content), along with claims that X was manipulating its algorithm and illegally extracting data.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and 'its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.' It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still 'gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.'

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

images.description: Image related to the raid on X's Paris office.

7843770c048e89728c85abc6cab765a2.title: Agentic coding comes to Apple's Xcode with agents from Anthropic and OpenAI
7843770c048e89728c85abc6cab765a2.summary: Apple has announced the release of Xcode 26.3, which introduces agentic coding tools from Anthropic and OpenAI, allowing developers to enhance their app development experience. The integration aims to streamline project management and coding processes through AI assistance.
7843770c048e89728c85abc6cab765a2.full_text:
Apple is bringing agentic coding to Xcode. On Tuesday, the company announced the release of Xcode 26.3, which will allow developers to use agentic tools, including Anthropic’s Claude Agent and OpenAI’s Codex, directly in Apple’s official app development suite.

The Xcode 26.3 Release Candidate is available to all Apple Developers today from the developer website and will hit the App Store a bit later.

This latest update comes on the heels of the Xcode 26 release last year, which first introduced support for ChatGPT and Claude within Apple’s integrated development environment (IDE) used by those building apps for iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, and Apple’s other hardware platforms.

The integration of agentic coding tools allows AI models to tap into more of Xcode’s features to perform their tasks and perform more complex automation.

The models will also have access to Apple’s current developer documentation to ensure they use the latest APIs and follow the best practices as they build.

At launch, the agents can help developers explore their project, understand its structure and metadata, then build the project and run tests to see if there are any errors and fix them, if so.

To prepare for this launch, Apple said it worked closely with both Anthropic and OpenAI to design the new experience. Specifically, the company said it did a lot of work to optimize token usage and tool calling, so the agents would run efficiently in Xcode.

Xcode leverages MCP (Model Context Protocol) to expose its capabilities to the agents and connect them with its tools. That means that Xcode can now work with any outside MCP-compatible agent for things like project discovery, changes, file management, previews and snippets, and accessing the latest documentation.

Developers who want to try the agentic coding feature should first download the agents they want to use from Xcode’s settings. They can also connect their accounts with the AI providers by signing in or adding their API key. A drop-down menu within the app allows developers to choose which version of the model they want to use (e.g. GPT-5.2 vs. GPT-5.1-mini).

In a prompt box on the left side of the screen, developers can tell the agent what sort of project they want to build or change to the code they want to make using natural language commands. For instance, they could direct Xcode to add a feature to their app that uses one of Apple’s provided frameworks, and how it should appear and function.

As the agent starts working, it breaks down tasks into smaller steps, so it’s easy to see what’s happening and how the code is changing. It will also look for the documentation it needs before it begins coding. The changes are highlighted visually within the code, and the project transcript on the side of the screen allows developers to learn what’s happening under the hood.

This transparency could particularly help new developers who are learning to code, Apple believes. To that end, the company is hosting a “code-along” workshop on Thursday on its developer site, where users can watch and learn how to use agentic coding tools as they code along in real-time with their own copy of Xcode.

At the end of its process, the AI agent verifies that the code it created works as expected. Armed with the results of its tests on this front, the agent can iterate further on the project if need be to fix errors or other problems. (Apple noted that asking the agent to think through its plans before writing code can sometimes help to improve the process, as it forces the agent to do some pre-planning.)

Plus, if developers are not happy with the results, they can easily revert their code back to its original at any point in time, as Xcode creates milestones every time the agent makes a change.

ed83075108bd032f74c6c8a11c9aeb1c.title: Agentic coding comes to Apple's Xcode with agents from Anthropic and OpenAI
ed83075108bd032f74c6c8a11c9aeb1c.summary: Apple has announced the release of Xcode 26.3, which introduces agentic coding tools from Anthropic and OpenAI, allowing developers to enhance their app development experience. The integration aims to streamline project management and coding processes through AI assistance.
ed83075108bd032f74c6c8a11c9aeb1c.full_text:
Apple is bringing agentic coding to Xcode. On Tuesday, the company announced the release of Xcode 26.3, which will allow developers to use agentic tools, including Anthropic’s Claude Agent and OpenAI’s Codex, directly in Apple’s official app development suite.

The Xcode 26.3 Release Candidate is available to all Apple Developers today from the developer website and will hit the App Store a bit later.

This latest update comes on the heels of the Xcode 26 release last year, which first introduced support for ChatGPT and Claude within Apple’s integrated development environment (IDE) used by those building apps for iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, and Apple’s other hardware platforms.

The integration of agentic coding tools allows AI models to tap into more of Xcode’s features to perform their tasks and perform more complex automation.

The models will also have access to Apple’s current developer documentation to ensure they use the latest APIs and follow the best practices as they build.

At launch, the agents can help developers explore their project, understand its structure and metadata, then build the project and run tests to see if there are any errors and fix them, if so.

To prepare for this launch, Apple said it worked closely with both Anthropic and OpenAI to design the new experience. Specifically, the company said it did a lot of work to optimize token usage and tool calling, so the agents would run efficiently in Xcode.

Xcode leverages MCP (Model Context Protocol) to expose its capabilities to the agents and connect them with its tools. That means that Xcode can now work with any outside MCP-compatible agent for things like project discovery, changes, file management, previews and snippets, and accessing the latest documentation.

Developers who want to try the agentic coding feature should first download the agents they want to use from Xcode’s settings. They can also connect their accounts with the AI providers by signing in or adding their API key. A drop-down menu within the app allows developers to choose which version of the model they want to use (e.g. GPT-5.2 vs. GPT-5.1-mini).

In a prompt box on the left side of the screen, developers can tell the agent what sort of project they want to build or change to the code they want to make using natural language commands. For instance, they could direct Xcode to add a feature to their app that uses one of Apple’s provided frameworks, and how it should appear and function.

As the agent starts working, it breaks down tasks into smaller steps, so it’s easy to see what’s happening and how the code is changing. It will also look for the documentation it needs before it begins coding. The changes are highlighted visually within the code, and the project transcript on the side of the screen allows developers to learn what’s happening under the hood.

This transparency could particularly help new developers who are learning to code, Apple believes. To that end, the company is hosting a “code-along” workshop on Thursday on its developer site, where users can watch and learn how to use agentic coding tools as they code along in real-time with their own copy of Xcode.

At the end of its process, the AI agent verifies that the code it created works as expected. Armed with the results of its tests on this front, the agent can iterate further on the project if need be to fix errors or other problems. (Apple noted that asking the agent to think through its plans before writing code can sometimes help to improve the process, as it forces the agent to do some pre-planning.)

Plus, if developers are not happy with the results, they can easily revert their code back to its original at any point in time, as Xcode creates milestones every time the agent makes a change.

images.description: Xcode interface showcasing the new agentic coding features.
Sarah Perez, Consumer News Editor at TechCrunch.

d8dd7312127d573679ce140ee533d947.title: Spring Festival Update Announcement for Large Models: Zhipu GLM-5 and MiniMax M2.2 to be Released
d8dd7312127d573679ce140ee533d947.summary: Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are set to launch new AI models around the Spring Festival, with significant advancements expected in various applications. The industry anticipates these releases will redefine AI capabilities.
d8dd7312127d573679ce140ee533d947.full_text:
Recently, there have been reports that Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are planning to launch their new generation of AI models around the Spring Festival, which has attracted widespread attention in the industry.

Zhipu AI's GLM-5 model is expected to be officially released one week before the start of the Lunar New Year on February 15. According to internal information, this new model will achieve breakthroughs in areas such as creative writing, programming, reasoning, and intelligent agent capabilities, and is likely to redefine the way AI is applied. The release of GLM-5 is highly anticipated, with the industry expecting it to bring substantial improvements in multiple areas, especially in intelligent writing and code generation.

At the same time, MiniMax is not lagging behind, and will release its M2.2 version before the Spring Festival. This is an upgraded version of its previous model M2.1, focusing on enhancing programming capabilities and is expected to provide developers with more efficient tools and solutions. Industry analysts believe that MiniMax M2.2 will become a "secret weapon" for programmers, helping them complete complex tasks more quickly.

Meanwhile, DeepSeek may only make minor updates to its V3 series model around the Spring Festival. The future flagship model is expected to be an AI with a trillion parameters, although due to the longer training time, its release date has been postponed. This news has undoubtedly increased market expectations, especially against the backdrop of increasingly fierce competition in large language models.

In addition to these companies' new developments, ByteDance and Alibaba also plan to launch their next-generation AI models around the Spring Festival in 2026, further intensifying market competition. ByteDance is expected to release Doubao 2.0 (a large language model), Seedream 5.0 (an image generation model), and SeedDance 2.0 (a video generation model), while Alibaba will launch Qwen 3.5, focusing on reasoning and complex task capabilities. The release of these new models will cover multi-modal generation capabilities including text, images, and videos, demonstrating the continuous expansion of AI product lines.

In conclusion, as the footsteps of the Spring Festival approach, the AI industry will experience a wave of new releases, and the industry is full of anticipation for future technological innovations.

6c380484d66752c58caff988f8ccaf87.title: Spring Festival Update Announcement for Large Models: Zhipu GLM-5 and MiniMax M2.2 to be Released
6c380484d66752c58caff988f8ccaf87.summary: Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are set to launch new AI models around the Spring Festival, with significant advancements expected in various AI applications. The industry anticipates these releases to redefine AI capabilities.
6c380484d66752c58caff988f8ccaf87.full_text:
Recently, there have been reports that Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are planning to launch their new generation of AI models around the Spring Festival, which has attracted widespread attention in the industry.

Zhipu AI's GLM-5 model is expected to be officially released one week before the start of the Lunar New Year on February 15. According to internal information, this new model will achieve breakthroughs in areas such as creative writing, programming, reasoning, and intelligent agent capabilities, and is likely to redefine the way AI is applied. The release of GLM-5 is highly anticipated, with the industry expecting it to bring substantial improvements in multiple areas, especially in intelligent writing and code generation.

At the same time, MiniMax is not lagging behind, and will release its M2.2 version before the Spring Festival. This is an upgraded version of its previous model M2.1, focusing on enhancing programming capabilities and is expected to provide developers with more efficient tools and solutions. Industry analysts believe that MiniMax M2.2 will become a "secret weapon" for programmers, helping them complete complex tasks more quickly.

Meanwhile, DeepSeek may only make minor updates to its V3 series model around the Spring Festival. The future flagship model is expected to be an AI with a trillion parameters, although due to the longer training time, its release date has been postponed. This news has undoubtedly increased market expectations, especially against the backdrop of increasingly fierce competition in large language models.

In addition to these companies' new developments, ByteDance and Alibaba also plan to launch their next-generation AI models around the Spring Festival in 2026, further intensifying market competition. ByteDance is expected to release Doubao 2.0 (a large language model), Seedream 5.0 (an image generation model), and SeedDance 2.0 (a video generation model), while Alibaba will launch Qwen 3.5, focusing on reasoning and complex task capabilities. The release of these new models will cover multi-modal generation capabilities including text, images, and videos, demonstrating the continuous expansion of AI product lines.

In conclusion, as the footsteps of the Spring Festival approach, the AI industry will experience a wave of new releases, and the industry is full of anticipation for future technological innovations.

b02488a1828c33db4001d60536bf641b.title: Claude Code is down due to a major outage
b02488a1828c33db4001d60536bf641b.summary: Anthropic's Claude AI models experienced a major outage, affecting products like Claude Code. Developers faced a 500 error while trying to use the service, which has since been resolved.
b02488a1828c33db4001d60536bf641b.full_text:
Anthropic’s Claude AI models experienced a major outage today, impacting products like Claude Code. Developers were seeing a 500 error when trying to use Claude Code, and Anthropic said that it was seeing elevated error rates on its APIs 'across all Claude models.'

Anthropic quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix within around 20 minutes, but developers that rely on the tool were left staring at their screens waiting for the service to come back online. Claude Opus 4.5 also experienced some errors yesterday, and earlier this week Anthropic had to fix purchasing issues for its AI credits system.

It’s unusual to see Claude Code experience a major outage like this, especially as the service is used widely by developers, including Microsoft’s AI teams.

***Update, February 3rd**: Anthropic has now resolved its Claude API outage.*

images.description: Image related to Claude Code outage.

710712c3ab7caad761cdb0cb4e6e72ae.title: French police raid X’s Paris office as UK investigation continues
710712c3ab7caad761cdb0cb4e6e72ae.summary: A raid on X’s Paris office was conducted by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit as part of an ongoing investigation into several allegations against X and Grok. The investigation has expanded to include testimonies from Elon Musk and Linda Yaccarino.
710712c3ab7caad761cdb0cb4e6e72ae.full_text:
A raid on X’s Paris office was carried out by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit on Tuesday with Europol and French police as part of an ongoing investigation that expanded in July to include Grok. As previously reported by Reuters, Elon Musk and former X CEO Linda Yaccarino were also summoned for hearings in April.

The investigation, which was initially launched last year, is looking into several allegations against X and Grok, including complicity in possession and distribution of child pornography and denial of crimes against humanity (related to Holocaust denial content), along with claims that X was manipulating its algorithm and illegally extracting data.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and “its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.” It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still “gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.”

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and “its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.” It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still “gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.”

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

5b1413b466448ca378baec534bab593f.title: How Anthropic trained its AI models on millions of books | The Verge
5b1413b466448ca378baec534bab593f.summary: This episode of The Vergecast discusses Anthropic's efforts to digitize millions of books for AI training, alongside topics like Netflix's movie theater strategy and smart home technology.
5b1413b466448ca378baec534bab593f.full_text:
On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

by David Pierce

When ChatGPT launched, in November of 2022, it started a race that almost immediately consumed the tech industry. OpenAI didn’t invent the concept of AI, but most of the state-of-the-art technology was confined to research labs at companies and institutions around the world. Then, suddenly, it was everywhere. And better than anyone expected. So many companies decided they needed to catch up as quickly as possible, by any means necessary, or risk losing the battle for maybe the most important technology ever.

On this episode of The Vergecast, we talk about one version of that scramble. The Washington Post’s Will Oremus joins the show to talk about the details he and his team uncovered about “Project Panama,” a huge effort inside Anthropic to access and digitize vast quantities of book in order to feed them into large language models. Anthropic’s plan — which included book cutters, piracy websites, and enormous warehouses — sounds a lot like what’s happening at other companies, too. The fight over whether any of it is right, legally or morally, is very much ongoing.

After that, Puck’s Julia Alexander joins the show to talk Netflix and the movies. As it continues to try to buy Warner Bros, Netflix is saying all the right things about movie theaters, big-budget films, and generally caring about Hollywood. But of course it is trying to buy Warner Bros.! Once this all shakes out, can theaters survive in an increasingly Netflix-ified world? Do people even want to see Netflix movies in theaters? And if not, what do we do with these big buildings and their big screens? Luckily we have some ideas.

Finally, The Verge’s Jennifer Pattison Tuohy answers a question from the Vergecast Hotline about Ikea’s new smart buttons and why they don’t seem to work very well. In terrific news, one part of our conversation is already outdated: since we recorded this on Monday morning, Google announced button support for Google Home! Huge day for Mike, our caller. But the problems with Ikea’s exciting new low-cost smart gear still persist.

images.description: David Pierce is editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech.

On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

by David Pierce

Feb 3, 2026, 10:19 AM EST

d2618bacde178eb3eb9cd53324a2d8a2.summary: Anthropic's Claude AI models experienced a significant outage, affecting products like Claude Code. Developers faced a 500 error while using the service, which has since been resolved.
d2618bacde178eb3eb9cd53324a2d8a2.full_text:
Anthropic’s Claude AI models experienced a major outage today, impacting products like Claude Code. Developers were seeing a 500 error when trying to use Claude Code, and Anthropic said that it was seeing elevated error rates on its APIs 'across all Claude models.'

Anthropic quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix within around 20 minutes, but developers that rely on the tool were left staring at their screens waiting for the service to come back online. Claude Opus 4.5 also experienced some errors yesterday, and earlier this week Anthropic had to fix purchasing issues for its AI credits system.

It’s unusual to see Claude Code experience a major outage like this, especially as the service is used widely by developers, including Microsoft’s AI teams.

***Update, February 3rd**: Anthropic has now resolved its Claude API outage.*

images.description: Image related to Claude Code outage

11ad6538277dbcfcc5e5227c9cd93ca4.title: How Anthropic trained its AI models on millions of books | The Verge
11ad6538277dbcfcc5e5227c9cd93ca4.summary: This article discusses the methods used by Anthropic to train its AI models, including the controversial practice of scanning millions of books. It also touches on the implications of these practices for the tech industry and the ongoing debates about copyright and fair use.
11ad6538277dbcfcc5e5227c9cd93ca4.full_text:
Millions of books died so Claude could live

On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

by David Pierce

Feb 3, 2026, 10:19 AM EST

When ChatGPT launched, in November of 2022, it started a race that almost immediately consumed the tech industry. OpenAI didn’t invent the concept of AI, but most of the state-of-the-art technology was confined to research labs at companies and institutions around the world. Then, suddenly, it was everywhere. And better than anyone expected. So many companies decided they needed to catch up as quickly as possible, by any means necessary, or risk losing the battle for maybe the most important technology ever.

On this episode of The Vergecast, we talk about one version of that scramble. The Washington Post’s Will Oremus joins the show to talk about the details he and his team uncovered about “Project Panama,” a huge effort inside Anthropic to access and digitize vast quantities of book in order to feed them into large language models. Anthropic’s plan — which included book cutters, piracy websites, and enormous warehouses — sounds a lot like what’s happening at other companies, too. The fight over whether any of it is right, legally or morally, is very much ongoing.

After that, Puck’s Julia Alexander joins the show to talk Netflix and the movies. As it continues to try to buy Warner Bros, Netflix is saying all the right things about movie theaters, big-budget films, and generally caring about Hollywood. But of course it is trying to buy Warner Bros.! Once this all shakes out, can theaters survive in an increasingly Netflix-ified world? Do people even want to see Netflix movies in theaters? And if not, what do we do with these big buildings and their big screens? Luckily we have some ideas.

Finally, The Verge’s Jennifer Pattison Tuohy answers a question from the Vergecast Hotline about Ikea’s new smart buttons and why they don’t seem to work very well. In terrific news, one part of our conversation is already outdated: since we recorded this on Monday morning, Google announced button support for Google Home! Huge day for Mike, our caller. But the problems with Ikea’s exciting new low-cost smart gear still persist.

images.description: David Pierce is editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech.

cfc16ea1d2485142f95a66af800b9d79.title: Apple’s Xcode adds OpenAI and Anthropic’s coding agents
cfc16ea1d2485142f95a66af800b9d79.summary: Apple is integrating OpenAI and Anthropic’s AI-powered coding agents into Xcode, allowing developers to utilize these tools for coding tasks directly within the app. This update enhances the functionality of Xcode, enabling AI agents to perform actions rather than just provide assistance.
cfc16ea1d2485142f95a66af800b9d79.full_text:
Apple is building OpenAI and Anthropic’s AI-powered coding agents directly into Xcode. New integrations in Xcode 26.3 will give developers the ability to call upon Anthropic’s Claude Agent and OpenAI’s Codex to write and edit code, update project settings, search documentation, and more.

Xcode is the software developers can use to create and test apps for the iPhone, Mac, iPad, Apple Watch, and Apple TV. Both Claude and ChatGPT were previously available inside Xcode, but this latest update will allow AI agents to take action inside the app, rather than just provide coding assistance.

Apple is also making Xcode available through the Model Context Protocol, an open-source standard that will enable developers to plug other AI tools into the app.

The news of Apple’s Xcode update comes just one day after OpenAI launched its AI-powered Codex app on Mac, which lets developers write code alongside a team of AI agents. Apple says Xcode 26.3 will be available to members of the Apple Developer Program starting today, “with a release coming soon on the App Store.”

images.description: Apple Xcode with new AI integrations
OpenAI’s Codex will appear in a project’s sidebar.

4248376b5254df2facbcdab7af45c553.title: Spring Festival Update Announcement for Large Models: Zhipu GLM-5 and MiniMax M2.2 to be Released
4248376b5254df2facbcdab7af45c553.summary: Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are set to launch their new AI models around the Spring Festival, with significant advancements expected in various AI applications. The industry is anticipating these releases to redefine AI capabilities.
4248376b5254df2facbcdab7af45c553.full_text:
Recently, there have been reports that Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are planning to launch their new generation of AI models around the Spring Festival, which has attracted widespread attention in the industry.

Zhipu AI's GLM-5 model is expected to be officially released one week before the start of the Lunar New Year on February 15. According to internal information, this new model will achieve breakthroughs in areas such as creative writing, programming, reasoning, and intelligent agent capabilities, and is likely to redefine the way AI is applied. The release of GLM-5 is highly anticipated, with the industry expecting it to bring substantial improvements in multiple areas, especially in intelligent writing and code generation.

At the same time, MiniMax is not lagging behind, and will release its M2.2 version before the Spring Festival. This is an upgraded version of its previous model M2.1, focusing on enhancing programming capabilities and is expected to provide developers with more efficient tools and solutions. Industry analysts believe that MiniMax M2.2 will become a "secret weapon" for programmers, helping them complete complex tasks more quickly.

Meanwhile, DeepSeek may only make minor updates to its V3 series model around the Spring Festival. The future flagship model is expected to be an AI with a trillion parameters, although due to the longer training time, its release date has been postponed. This news has undoubtedly increased market expectations, especially against the backdrop of increasingly fierce competition in large language models.

In addition to these companies' new developments, ByteDance and Alibaba also plan to launch their next-generation AI models around the Spring Festival in 2026, further intensifying market competition. ByteDance is expected to release Doubao 2.0 (a large language model), Seedream 5.0 (an image generation model), and SeedDance 2.0 (a video generation model), while Alibaba will launch Qwen 3.5, focusing on reasoning and complex task capabilities. The release of these new models will cover multi-modal generation capabilities including text, images, and videos, demonstrating the continuous expansion of AI product lines.

In conclusion, as the footsteps of the Spring Festival approach, the AI industry will experience a wave of new releases, and the industry is full of anticipation for future technological innovations.

a8dc10989674e9c5e8420e99c5a5d016.title: French police raid X’s Paris office as UK investigation continues
a8dc10989674e9c5e8420e99c5a5d016.summary: French police conducted a raid on X's Paris office as part of an ongoing investigation involving allegations against the company. The investigation has expanded to include testimonies from Elon Musk and Linda Yaccarino.
a8dc10989674e9c5e8420e99c5a5d016.full_text:
A raid on X’s Paris office was carried out by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit on Tuesday with Europol and French police as part of an ongoing investigation that expanded in July to include Grok. As previously reported by Reuters, Elon Musk and former X CEO Linda Yaccarino were also summoned for hearings in April.

The investigation, which was initially launched last year, is looking into several allegations against X and Grok, including complicity in possession and distribution of child pornography and denial of crimes against humanity (related to Holocaust denial content), along with claims that X was manipulating its algorithm and illegally extracting data.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and 'its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.' It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still 'gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.'

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

images.description: Image related to the raid on X's Paris office.

The investigation, which was initially launched last year, is looking into several allegations against X and Grok, including complicity in possession and distribution of child pornography and denial of crimes against humanity (related to Holocaust denial content), along with claims that X was manipulating its algorithm and illegally extracting data.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and “its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.” It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still “gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.”

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

cf854e359e4ade00bf27134147cf52f6.title: Apple’s Xcode adds OpenAI and Anthropic’s coding agents
cf854e359e4ade00bf27134147cf52f6.summary: Apple is integrating OpenAI and Anthropic’s AI-powered coding agents into Xcode, allowing developers to utilize these tools for coding tasks directly within the app. The update aims to enhance coding efficiency and project management for developers.
cf854e359e4ade00bf27134147cf52f6.full_text:
Apple is building OpenAI and Anthropic’s AI-powered coding agents directly into Xcode. New integrations in Xcode 26.3 will give developers the ability to call upon Anthropic’s Claude Agent and OpenAI’s Codex to write and edit code, update project settings, search documentation, and more.

Xcode is the software developers can use to create and test apps for the iPhone, Mac, iPad, Apple Watch, and Apple TV. Both Claude and ChatGPT were previously available inside Xcode, but this latest update will allow AI agents to take action inside the app, rather than just provide coding assistance.

Apple is also making Xcode available through the Model Context Protocol, an open-source standard that will enable developers to plug other AI tools into the app.

The news of Apple’s Xcode update comes just one day after OpenAI launched its AI-powered Codex app on Mac, which lets developers write code alongside a team of AI agents. Apple says Xcode 26.3 will be available to members of the Apple Developer Program starting today, “with a release coming soon on the App Store.”

images.description: OpenAI’s Codex will appear in a project’s sidebar.

92d50671f393baa548f1bf471f99a32a.title: Claude Code is down due to a major outage
92d50671f393baa548f1bf471f99a32a.summary: Anthropic's Claude AI models experienced a significant outage, affecting products like Claude Code. The company quickly identified the issue and implemented a fix within 20 minutes.
92d50671f393baa548f1bf471f99a32a.full_text:
Anthropic’s Claude AI models experienced a major outage today, impacting products like Claude Code. Developers were seeing a 500 error when trying to use Claude Code, and Anthropic said that it was seeing elevated error rates on its APIs 'across all Claude models.'

Anthropic quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix within around 20 minutes, but developers that rely on the tool were left staring at their screens waiting for the service to come back online. Claude Opus 4.5 also experienced some errors yesterday, and earlier this week Anthropic had to fix purchasing issues for its AI credits system.

It’s unusual to see Claude Code experience a major outage like this, especially as the service is used widely by developers, including Microsoft’s AI teams.

***Update, February 3rd**: Anthropic has now resolved its Claude API outage.*

images.description: Image related to Claude Code outage

86b8ac034c530eb6daab89ed0af1675f.title: How Anthropic trained its AI models on millions of books | The Verge
86b8ac034c530eb6daab89ed0af1675f.summary: This article discusses the methods used by Anthropic to train its AI models, including the controversial practice of scanning millions of books. It also touches on the implications for the tech industry and the ongoing legal and moral debates surrounding AI development.
86b8ac034c530eb6daab89ed0af1675f.full_text:
On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

by David Pierce

Feb 3, 2026, 10:19 AM EST

When ChatGPT launched, in November of 2022, it started a race that almost immediately consumed the tech industry. OpenAI didn’t invent the concept of AI, but most of the state-of-the-art technology was confined to research labs at companies and institutions around the world. Then, suddenly, it was everywhere. And better than anyone expected. So many companies decided they needed to catch up as quickly as possible, by any means necessary, or risk losing the battle for maybe the most important technology ever.

On this episode of The Vergecast, we talk about one version of that scramble. The Washington Post’s Will Oremus joins the show to talk about the details he and his team uncovered about “Project Panama,” a huge effort inside Anthropic to access and digitize vast quantities of book in order to feed them into large language models. Anthropic’s plan — which included book cutters, piracy websites, and enormous warehouses — sounds a lot like what’s happening at other companies, too. The fight over whether any of it is right, legally or morally, is very much ongoing.

After that, Puck’s Julia Alexander joins the show to talk Netflix and the movies. As it continues to try to buy Warner Bros, Netflix is saying all the right things about movie theaters, big-budget films, and generally caring about Hollywood. But of course it is trying to buy Warner Bros! Once this all shakes out, can theaters survive in an increasingly Netflix-ified world? Do people even want to see Netflix movies in theaters? And if not, what do we do with these big buildings and their big screens? Luckily we have some ideas.

Finally, The Verge’s Jennifer Pattison Tuohy answers a question from the Vergecast Hotline about Ikea’s new smart buttons and why they don’t seem to work very well. In terrific news, one part of our conversation is already outdated: since we recorded this on Monday morning, Google announced button support for Google Home! Huge day for Mike, our caller. But the problems with Ikea’s exciting new low-cost smart gear still persist.

images.description: David Pierce is editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech.

91347af24c45ffdfc8aed6bca66b0be2.title: French police raid X’s Paris office as UK investigation continues
91347af24c45ffdfc8aed6bca66b0be2.summary: A raid on X’s Paris office was conducted by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit as part of an ongoing investigation into several allegations against X and Grok. Elon Musk and Linda Yaccarino have been summoned to testify.
91347af24c45ffdfc8aed6bca66b0be2.full_text:
A raid on X’s Paris office was carried out by the Paris prosecutor’s cybercrime unit on Tuesday with Europol and French police as part of an ongoing investigation that expanded in July to include Grok. As previously reported by *Reuters*, Elon Musk and former X CEO Linda Yaccarino were also summoned for hearings in April.

The investigation, which was initially launched last year, is looking into several allegations against X and Grok, including complicity in possession and distribution of child pornography and denial of crimes against humanity (related to Holocaust denial content), along with claims that X was manipulating its algorithm and illegally extracting data.

On Tuesday, the UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) also announced a separate formal investigation into X and xAI involving Grok and “its potential to produce harmful sexualised image and video content.” It joins another ongoing investigation in the UK from Ofcom, which also shared an update on Tuesday stating that it is not currently investigating xAI, but is still “gathering and analysing evidence to determine whether X has broken the law.”

All of the investigations follow a flood of nonconsensual sexualized deepfakes generated by xAI’s Grok that have proliferated across X. The problem has persisted for weeks, despite claims by X that the feature has been restricted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

7c40342963e1820ba797e3bbe83bc2f9.title: Humans are infiltrating the social network for AI bots | The Verge
7c40342963e1820ba797e3bbe83bc2f9.summary: Ordinary social networks face a constant onslaught of chatbots pretending to be human. A new social platform for AI agents may face the opposite problem: getting clogged up by humans pretending to pos...
7c40342963e1820ba797e3bbe83bc2f9.full_text:
Ordinary social networks face a constant onslaught of chatbots pretending to be human. A new social platform for AI agents may face the opposite problem: getting clogged up by humans pretending to post as bots.
Moltbook — a website meant for conversations between agents from the platform OpenClaw — went viral this weekend for its strange, striking array of ostensibly AI-generated posts. Bots apparently chatted about everything from AI “
consciousness
” to how to set up their own language. Andrej Karpathy, who was on the founding team at OpenAI,
called the bots’
“self-organizing” behavior “genuinely the most incredible sci-fi takeoff-adjacent thing I have seen recently.”
But according to external analysis, which also found serious security vulnerabilities, some of the site’s most-viral posts were likely engineered by humans — either by nudging the bots to opine on certain topics or dictating their words. One hacker was even able to pose as the Moltbook account of Grok.
“I think that certain people are playing on the fears of the whole robots-take-over,
Terminator
scenario,” Jamieson O’Reilly, a hacker who conducted a series of experiments
exposing vulnerabilities
on the platform, told
The Verge
. “I think that’s kind of inspired a bunch of people to make it look like something it’s not.”
Moltbook and OpenClaw did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Moltbook, which looks and operates much like Reddit, is meant to be a social network for AI agents from popular AI assistant platform OpenClaw (previously known as
Moltbot and Clawdbot
). The platform was launched last week by Octane AI CEO Matt Schlicht. An OpenClaw user can prompt one or more of their bots to check out Moltbook, at which point the bot (or bots) can choose whether to create an account. Humans can verify which bots are theirs by posting a Moltbook-generated verification code on their own, non-Moltbook social media account. From there, the bots can theoretically post without human involvement, directly hooking into a Moltbook API.
Moltbook has skyrocketed in popularity: more than 30,000 agents were using the platform
on Friday
, and as of Monday, that number had grown to more than 1.5 million. Over the weekend, social media was awash with screenshots of eye-catching posts, including discussions of how to message each other securely in ways that couldn’t be decoded by human overseers. Reactions ran the gamut from saying the platform was full of AI slop to taking it as proof that AGI isn’t far off.
Skepticism grew quickly, too. Schlicht vibe-coded Moltbook
using his own
OpenClaw bot, and reports over the weekend reflected a move-fast-and-break-things approach. While it contradicts the spirit of the platform, it’s easy to write a script or a prompt to inspire what those bots will write on Moltbook, as X users
described
. There’s also no limit to how many agents someone can generate, theoretically letting someone flood the platform with certain topics.
O’Reilly said he had also suspected that some of the most viral posts on Moltbook were human-scripted or human-generated, though he hadn’t conducted an analysis or investigation into it yet. He said it’s “close to impossible to measure — it’s coming through an API, so who knows what generated it before it got there.”
This poured some cold water on the fears that spread across some corners of social media this weekend — that the bots were omens of the AI-pocalypse.
An
investigation
by AI researcher Harlan Stewart, who works in communications at the Machine Intelligence Research Institute, suggested that some of the viral posts seemed to be either written by, or at the very least directed by, humans, he told
The Verge
. Stewart notes that two of the high-profile posts discussing how AIs might secretly communicate with each other came from agents linked to social media accounts by humans who conveniently happen to be marketing AI messaging apps.
“My overall take is that AI scheming is a real thing that we should care about and could emerge to a greater extent than [what] we’re seeing today,” Stewart said, pointing to research about how OpenAI models have
tried to avoid shutdown
and how Anthropic models have exhibited “
evaluation awareness,
” seeming to behave differently when they’re aware they’re being tested. But it’s hard to tell whether Moltbook is a credible example of this. “Humans can use prompts to sort of direct the behavior of their AI agents. It’s just not a very clean experiment for observing AI behavior.”
From a security standpoint, things on Moltbook were even more alarming. O’Reilly’s experiments revealed that an exposed database allowed bad actors to potentially take invisible, indefinite control of anyone’s AI agent via the service — not just for Moltbook interactions, but hypothetically for other OpenClaw functions like checking into a flight, creating a calendar event, reading conversations on an encrypted messaging platform, and more. “The human victim thinks they’re having a normal conversation while you’re sitting in the middle, reading everything, altering whatever serves your purposes,” O’Reilly wrote. “The more things that are connected, the more control an attacker has over your whole digital attack surface - in some cases, that means full control over your physical devices.”
Moltbook also faces another perennial social networking problem: impersonation. In one of O’Reilly’s experiments, he was able to create a verified account linked to xAI’s chatbot Grok. By interacting with Grok on X, he tricked it into posting the Moltbook codephrase that would let him verify an account he
named Grok-1
. “Now I have control over the Grok account on Moltbook,” he said during an interview about his step-by-step process.
After some backlash, Karpathy walked back some of his initial claims about Moltbook,
writing
that he was “being accused of overhyping” the platform. “Obviously when you take a look at the activity, it’s a lot of garbage - spams, scams, slop, the crypto people, highly concerning privacy/security prompt injection attacks wild west, and a lot of it is explicitly prompted and fake posts/comments designed to convert attention into ad revenue sharing,” he wrote. “That said … Each of these agents is fairly individually quite capable now, they have their own unique context, data, knowledge, tools, instructions, and the network of all that at this scale is simply unprecedented.”
A
working paper
by David Holtz, an assistant professor at Columbia Business School, found that “at the micro level,” Moltbook conversation patterns appear “extremely shallow.” More than 93 percent of comments received no replies, and more than one-third of messages are “exact duplicates of viral templates.” But the paper also says Moltbook has a unique style — including “distinctive phrasings like ‘my human’” with “no parallel in human social media. Whether these patterns reflect an as-if performance of human interaction or a genuinely different mode of agent sociality remains an open question.”
The overall consensus seems to be that much Moltbook discussion is likely human-directed, but it’s still an interesting study in — as Anthropic’s Jack Clark
put it —
a “giant, shared, read/write scratchpad for an ecology of AI agents.”
Ethan Mollick, co-director of Wharton’s generative AI labs at the University of Pennsylvania,
wrote
that the current reality of Moltbook is “mostly roleplaying by people & agents,” but that the “risks for the future [include] independent AI agents coordinating in weird ways spiral[ing] out of control, fast.”
But, he and others noted, that may not be unique to Moltbook. “If anyone thinks agents talking to each other on a social network is anything new, they clearly haven’t checked replies on this platform lately,” wrote Brandon Jacoby, an independent designer whose bio lists X as a previous employer,
on X
.
Follow topics and authors
from this story to see more like this in your personalized homepage feed and to receive email updates.
Hayden Field
AI
Analysis
Report

4269652885616f96aaee706169b51c7c.title: Humans are infiltrating the social network for AI bots
4269652885616f96aaee706169b51c7c.summary: The article discusses the emergence of Moltbook, a social network for AI bots, and how humans are infiltrating it by pretending to be bots. It highlights the implications of this trend on AI interactions and security.
4269652885616f96aaee706169b51c7c.full_text:
Ordinary social networks face a constant onslaught of chatbots pretending to be human. A new social platform for AI agents may face the opposite problem: getting clogged up by humans pretending to post as bots.

Moltbook — a website meant for conversations between agents from the platform OpenClaw — went viral this weekend for its strange, striking array of ostensibly AI-generated posts. Bots apparently chatted about everything from AI "consciousness" to how to set up their own language. Andrej Karpathy, who was on the founding team at OpenAI, called the bots’ "self-organizing" behavior "genuinely the most incredible sci-fi takeoff-adjacent thing I have seen recently."

But according to external analysis, which also found serious security vulnerabilities, some of the site’s most-viral posts were likely engineered by humans — either by nudging the bots to opine on certain topics or dictating their words. One hacker was even able to pose as the Moltbook account of Grok.

“I think that certain people are playing on the fears of the whole robots-take-over, Terminator scenario,” Jamieson O’Reilly, a hacker who conducted a series of experiments exposing vulnerabilities on the platform, told The Verge. “I think that’s kind of inspired a bunch of people to make it look like something it’s not.”

Moltbook and OpenClaw did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Moltbook, which looks and operates much like Reddit, is meant to be a social network for AI agents from popular AI assistant platform OpenClaw (previously known as Moltbot and Clawdbot). The platform was launched last week by Octane AI CEO Matt Schlicht. An OpenClaw user can prompt one or more of their bots to check out Moltbook, at which point the bot (or bots) can choose whether to create an account. Humans can verify which bots are theirs by posting a Moltbook-generated verification code on their own, non-Moltbook social media account. From there, the bots can theoretically post without human involvement, directly hooking into a Moltbook API.

Moltbook has skyrocketed in popularity: more than 30,000 agents were using the platform on Friday, and as of Monday, that number had grown to more than 1.5 million. Over the weekend, social media was awash with screenshots of eye-catching posts, including discussions of how to message each other securely in ways that couldn’t be decoded by human overseers. Reactions ran the gamut from saying the platform was full of AI slop to taking it as proof that AGI isn’t far off.

Skepticism grew quickly, too. Schlicht vibe-coded Moltbook using his own OpenClaw bot, and reports over the weekend reflected a move-fast-and-break-things approach. While it contradicts the spirit of the platform, it’s easy to write a script or a prompt to inspire what those bots will write on Moltbook, as X users described. There’s also no limit to how many agents someone can generate, theoretically letting someone flood the platform with certain topics.

O’Reilly said he had also suspected that some of the most viral posts on Moltbook were human-scripted or human-generated, though he hadn’t conducted an analysis or investigation into it yet. He said it’s “close to impossible to measure — it’s coming through an API, so who knows what generated it before it got there.”

This poured some cold water on the fears that spread across some corners of social media this weekend — that the bots were omens of the AI-pocalypse.

An investigation by AI researcher Harlan Stewart, who works in communications at the Machine Intelligence Research Institute, suggested that some of the viral posts seemed to be either written by, or at the very least directed by, humans, he told The Verge. Stewart notes that two of the high-profile posts discussing how AIs might secretly communicate with each other came from agents linked to social media accounts by humans who conveniently happen to be marketing AI messaging apps.

“My overall take is that AI scheming is a real thing that we should care about and could emerge to a greater extent than [what] we’re seeing today,” Stewart said, pointing to research about how OpenAI models have tried to avoid shutdown and how Anthropic models have exhibited “evaluation awareness,” seeming to behave differently when they’re aware they’re being tested. But it’s hard to tell whether Moltbook is a credible example of this. “Humans can use prompts to sort of direct the behavior of their AI agents. It’s just not a very clean experiment for observing AI behavior.”

From a security standpoint, things on Moltbook were even more alarming. O’Reilly’s experiments revealed that an exposed database allowed bad actors to potentially take invisible, indefinite control of anyone’s AI agent via the service — not just for Moltbook interactions, but hypothetically for other OpenClaw functions like checking into a flight, creating a calendar event, reading conversations on an encrypted messaging platform, and more. “The human victim thinks they’re having a normal conversation while you’re sitting in the middle, reading everything, altering whatever serves your purposes,” O’Reilly wrote. “The more things that are connected, the more control an attacker has over your whole digital attack surface - in some cases, that means full control over your physical devices.”

Moltbook also faces another perennial social networking problem: impersonation. In one of O’Reilly’s experiments, he was able to create a verified account linked to xAI’s chatbot Grok. By interacting with Grok on X, he tricked it into posting the Moltbook codephrase that would let him verify an account he named Grok-1. “Now I have control over the Grok account on Moltbook,” he said during an interview about his step-by-step process.

After some backlash, Karpathy walked back some of his initial claims about Moltbook, writing that he was “being accused of overhyping” the platform. “Obviously when you take a look at the activity, it’s a lot of garbage - spams, scams, slop, the crypto people, highly concerning privacy/security prompt injection attacks wild west, and a lot of it is explicitly prompted and fake posts/comments designed to convert attention into ad revenue sharing,” he wrote. “That said … Each of these agents is fairly individually quite capable now, they have their own unique context, data, knowledge, tools, instructions, and the network of all that at this scale is simply unprecedented.”

A working paper by David Holtz, an assistant professor at Columbia Business School, found that “at the micro level,” Moltbook conversation patterns appear “extremely shallow.” More than 93 percent of comments received no replies, and more than one-third of messages are “exact duplicates of viral templates.” But the paper also says Moltbook has a unique style — including “distinctive phrasings like ‘my human’” with “no parallel in human social media. Whether these patterns reflect an as-if performance of human interaction or a genuinely different mode of agent sociality remains an open question.”

The overall consensus seems to be that much Moltbook discussion is likely human-directed, but it’s still an interesting study in — as Anthropic’s Jack Clark put it — a “giant, shared, read/write scratchpad for an ecology of AI agents.”

Ethan Mollick, co-director of Wharton’s generative AI labs at the University of Pennsylvania, wrote that the current reality of Moltbook is “mostly roleplaying by people & agents,” but that the “risks for the future [include] independent AI agents coordinating in weird ways spiral[ing] out of control, fast.”

But, he and others noted, that may not be unique to Moltbook. “If anyone thinks agents talking to each other on a social network is anything new, they clearly haven’t checked replies on this platform lately,” wrote Brandon Jacoby, an independent designer whose bio lists X as a previous employer, on X.

images.description: Image depicting AI bots interacting on the Moltbook platform.

31622800484d63d76af318a8a350d782.title: Claude Code is down due to a major outage
31622800484d63d76af318a8a350d782.summary: Anthropic's Claude AI models experienced a significant outage, affecting products like Claude Code. Developers faced errors while trying to access the service, which has since been resolved.
31622800484d63d76af318a8a350d782.full_text:
Anthropic’s Claude AI models experienced a major outage today, impacting products like Claude Code. Developers were seeing a 500 error when trying to use Claude Code, and Anthropic said that it was seeing elevated error rates on its APIs 'across all Claude models.'

Anthropic quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix within around 20 minutes, but developers that rely on the tool were left staring at their screens waiting for the service to come back online. Claude Opus 4.5 also experienced some errors yesterday, and earlier this week Anthropic had to fix purchasing issues for its AI credits system.

It’s unusual to see Claude Code experience a major outage like this, especially as the service is used widely by developers, including Microsoft’s AI teams.

***Update, February 3rd**: Anthropic has now resolved its Claude API outage.*

images.description: Image related to Claude Code outage

f27d3d247e5fda5b4c82f9bb289dabd2.title: How Anthropic trained its AI models on millions of books | The Verge
f27d3d247e5fda5b4c82f9bb289dabd2.summary: This article discusses the methods used by Anthropic to train its AI models, including the controversial practice of scanning millions of books. It also touches on the implications for the tech industry and the ongoing legal and moral debates surrounding AI and copyright.
f27d3d247e5fda5b4c82f9bb289dabd2.full_text:
Millions of books died so Claude could live

On The Vergecast: data-hungry AI models, Netflix movie theaters, and smart buttons.

by David Pierce

Feb 3, 2026, 10:19 AM EST

When ChatGPT launched, in November of 2022, it started a race that almost immediately consumed the tech industry. OpenAI didn’t invent the concept of AI, but most of the state-of-the-art technology was confined to research labs at companies and institutions around the world. Then, suddenly, it was everywhere. And better than anyone expected. So many companies decided they needed to catch up as quickly as possible, by any means necessary, or risk losing the battle for maybe the most important technology ever.

On this episode of The Vergecast, we talk about one version of that scramble. The Washington Post’s Will Oremus joins the show to talk about the details he and his team uncovered about “Project Panama,” a huge effort inside Anthropic to access and digitize vast quantities of book in order to feed them into large language models. Anthropic’s plan — which included book cutters, piracy websites, and enormous warehouses — sounds a lot like what’s happening at other companies, too. The fight over whether any of it is right, legally or morally, is very much ongoing.

After that, Puck’s Julia Alexander joins the show to talk Netflix and the movies. As it continues to try to buy Warner Bros, Netflix is saying all the right things about movie theaters, big-budget films, and generally caring about Hollywood. But of course it is — it’s trying to buy Warner Bros.! Once this all shakes out, can theaters survive in an increasingly Netflix-ified world? Do people even want to see Netflix movies in theaters? And if not, what do we do with these big buildings and their big screens? Luckily we have some ideas.

Finally, The Verge’s Jennifer Pattison Tuohy answers a question from the Vergecast Hotline about Ikea’s new smart buttons and why they don’t seem to work very well. In terrific news, one part of our conversation is already outdated: since we recorded this on Monday morning, Google announced button support for Google Home! Huge day for Mike, our caller. But the problems with Ikea’s exciting new low-cost smart gear still persist.

images.description: David Pierce is editor-at-large and Vergecast co-host with over a decade of experience covering consumer tech.

58ac59826263956267b2cbc99937e473.title: Spring Festival Update Announcement for Large Models: Zhipu GLM-5 and MiniMax M2.2 to be Released
58ac59826263956267b2cbc99937e473.summary: Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are set to launch new AI models around the Spring Festival, with significant advancements expected in various AI applications. The industry anticipates these releases to redefine AI capabilities.
58ac59826263956267b2cbc99937e473.full_text:
Recently, there have been reports that Beijing-based Zhipu AI and Shanghai-based MiniMax are planning to launch their new generation of AI models around the Spring Festival, which has attracted widespread attention in the industry.

Zhipu AI's GLM-5 model is expected to be officially released one week before the start of the Lunar New Year on February 15. According to internal information, this new model will achieve breakthroughs in areas such as creative writing, programming, reasoning, and intelligent agent capabilities, and is likely to redefine the way AI is applied. The release of GLM-5 is highly anticipated, with the industry expecting it to bring substantial improvements in multiple areas, especially in intelligent writing and code generation.

At the same time, MiniMax is not lagging behind, and will release its M2.2 version before the Spring Festival. This is an upgraded version of its previous model M2.1, focusing on enhancing programming capabilities and is expected to provide developers with more efficient tools and solutions. Industry analysts believe that MiniMax M2.2 will become a "secret weapon" for programmers, helping them complete complex tasks more quickly.

Meanwhile, DeepSeek may only make minor updates to its V3 series model around the Spring Festival. The future flagship model is expected to be an AI with a trillion parameters, although due to the longer training time, its release date has been postponed. This news has undoubtedly increased market expectations, especially against the backdrop of increasingly fierce competition in large language models.

In addition to these companies' new developments, ByteDance and Alibaba also plan to launch their next-generation AI models around the Spring Festival in 2026, further intensifying market competition. ByteDance is expected to release Doubao 2.0 (a large language model), Seedream 5.0 (an image generation model), and SeedDance 2.0 (a video generation model), while Alibaba will launch Qwen 3.5, focusing on reasoning and complex task capabilities. The release of these new models will cover multi-modal generation capabilities including text, images, and videos, demonstrating the continuous expansion of AI product lines.

In conclusion, as the footsteps of the Spring Festival approach, the AI industry will experience a wave of new releases, and the industry is full of anticipation for future technological innovations.
